qas.question: When were the Constantinian basilicas built?
In what part of the church was the monumental entrance typically placed?
What type of architecture did the Carolingian Empire bring back into use?
What is a notable architectural feature of the basilica?
How is the transept positioned in relation to the nave?

context: Few large stone buildings were constructed between the Constantinian basilicas of the <a0_0>4th century<a0_0/> and the 8th century, although many smaller ones were built during the 6th and 7th centuries. By the beginning of the 8th century, the Carolingian Empire revived <a2_0>the basilica<a2_0/> form of architecture. One feature of the basilica is the use of a <a3_0>transept<a3_0/>, or the "arms" of a cross-shaped building that are <a4_0>perpendicular<a4_0/> to the long nave. Other new features of religious architecture include the crossing tower and a monumental entrance to the church, usually at <a1_0>the west end<a1_0/> of the building.
